greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal value of the reverse binary expansion of the prime numbers.
comment: 15 of the first 16 terms happen to be prime. As terms increase, the preponderance of primes apparently decreases.
formula: a(n) = Decimal(reverse(Binary(p(n)))) where p(n) is the n-th prime.
example: a(14) = 53 because the 14th prime is 43, or 101011 binary; reverse of 101011 is 110101, or 53 decimal.
maple: a:= proc(n) local m, r; m, r:= ithprime(n), 0;
while m>0 do r:= r*2+irem(m, 2, 'm') od; r
mathematica: GrayCodeList[k_] := Module[{b = IntegerDigits[k, 2], i}, Do[ If[b[[i - 1]] == 1, b[[i]] = 1 - b[[i]]], {i, Length[b], 2, -1} ]; b ]; a[n_] := GrayCodeList[Prime[n]]; Table[Sum[a[n][[m + 1]]*2^m, {m, 0, Length[a[n]] - 1}], {n, 1, 200}] (* _Roger L. Bagula_ and _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 21 2008 *)
results.author: _Gil Broussard_, Oct 21 2004
